sentence: The first-day success of file-sharing Dropbox's (DBX) initial public offering last month and music service Spotify Technology's (SPOT) direct listing last week suggest a rosy IPO market for late-stage private companies, many of them unicorns, after several false starts in the past few years.

The question, however, is the shortage of profitable unicorns-Dropbox, in its 11 year, posted $1.1 billion in revenue last year but a $111.7 million loss-and an abundance of late-state private funding.
With its $95 billion fund, SoftBank Group (9984.Japan) alone could provide the equivalent of three years' worth of U.S. IPO funding.

Yogesh Amle, who runs the San Francisco-based software practice at Union Square Advisors, a technology-focused boutique investment bank, works with venture capitalists on funding unicorns, mergers and acquisitions and financing.
It's a field rife with possibilities-and suspended public debuts.

Yet Amle, 41, who was educated in India, Singapore, and the U.S. and has lived and worked in more than 25 countries across three continents, remains bullish on the tech IPO climate, drawing on a professional career as diverse as his travels.
Barron's: What impact, if any, have the successful IPO of Dropbox and direct listing of Spotify, respectively, influenced the chances of more unicorns going public this year?
Amle: These successes will definitely inspire confidence in other unicorns to take the next step toward a public offering.
Do you expect late-stage financing to continue to flourish for private companies-meaning that Uber, Airbnb and others will continue to stay private?
The late-stage financing market is still flush with capital.
This market will continue to provide a source of capital and secondary liquidity to unicorns that aren't ready or do not want to go public.
Private-company valuations will eventually converge toward expected public-company valuations, as that is the eventual path for many.
Have you worked with VCs on the funding of unicorns?
Yes.
I have active dialogue with current and prospective unicorns and their respective VC investors in the software space.

Last year, I provided capital-raising advice to several enterprise software companies and/or their investors, including: SpringCM, a cloud content and contracts lifecycle management firm; Riversand Technologies, a cloud data-management firm; and Denodo Technologies, a leader in enterprise data virtualization.
Why are Dropbox and Zscaler (ZS) significant?
The Zscaler and Dropbox IPOs show the pent-up demand for technology IPOs.
Last year was the best IPO market after years of decline, and 2018 is looking even better.
The success of both of these IPOs is important for the health of the technology IPO markets and other prospective issuers this year.
If either of them doesn't perform well, that could scare investors back into their cocoons.
However, if both are successful-which they have been, so far-that could open the window even wider for other issuers.
What else is in the IPO pipeline?
Both DocuSign and Pivotal Software have filed recent IPOs.
There are at least a handful of pre-IPO companies that have filed in the past but did not go public at the time.
In light of the recent successes, we could and should expect many of these companies to revisit their timeline.
What does the health of this pipeline depend on?
The health of the IPO pipeline depends on the continued demand from investors for high-growth and disruptive-technology stories and their appetite for exposure to this technology IPO asset class.
On the supply side, the continued success of these IPOs will be an important determinant of future success of the pipeline.
Successful M&A stories like MuleSoft, which was just acquired by Salesforce.com (CRM) are additional boosters for companies looking to go public.
Because as the old adage goes, an IPO is often an intermediate stop for a strategic exit.
